title: 105_s1993
content: The "Medicare Home Health Equity Act of 1998" is also known as the Act. It revises the home health interim payment formula. The "Medicare Home Health Equity Act of 1998" revises the home health interim payment formula by increasing cost limits and changing additions to cost limits for services provided by home health agencies. The "Medicare Home Health Equity Act of 1998" revises the home health interim payment formula by setting agency-specific per beneficiary annual limitations based on national and regional average costs, updated by the home health market basket index. The limitations are calculated using a 75-25 percent split between costs from 1994 and 1995, adjusted for the agency's patient count. The "Medicare Home Health Equity Act of 1998" revises the home health interim payment formula by setting agency-specific per beneficiary annual limitations based on national and regional average costs, updated by the home health market basket index. The labor-related portion of the costs is adjusted by the area wage index applicable for the agency's location. Conforming amendments are made to ensure beneficiaries use services from only one home health agency. The "Medicare Home Health Equity Act of 1998" sets agency-specific per beneficiary annual limitations to prevent circumvention of the clause. Amendments are made to the Social Security Act to ensure compliance with the Balanced Budget Act of 1997. Effective date for the amendments is retroactive to the enactment of the Balanced Budget Act. The "Medicare Home Health Equity Act of 1998" establishes per beneficiary annual limitations for agencies to prevent circumvention. Amendments to the Social Security Act ensure compliance with the Balanced Budget Act of 1997, with retroactive effect. The "Medicare Home Health Equity Act of 1998" requires the Director of the Congressional Budget Office to estimate savings to the Medicare program resulting from the interim payment system for home health services. If the estimated savings exceed previous estimates, certification is required. The Director certifies excess savings to the Secretary of Health and Human Services under the Balanced Budget Act of 1997. Adjustments are made to payments to home health agencies for outliers due to events beyond agency control or extraordinary circumstances. Adjustments to payments to home health agencies may be made if costs exceed payment limits or if the Secretary deems it appropriate. The total amount of adjustments in a year cannot exceed the certified amount, and payments may be reduced proportionally if adjustments would exceed the certified amount.
